dt: {bc}to come into possession or control of often by unspecified means

dt.t: The team {it}acquired{/it} three new players this year.

dt: {bc}to come to have as a new or added characteristic, trait, or ability (as by sustained effort or natural selection)
{bc}to locate and hold (a desired object) in a detector

et: borrowed from Latin {it}acquīrere,{/it} from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}quaerere{/it} "to seek, gain, obtain, enquire"; replacing earlier {it}aquere,{/it} going back to Middle English {it}aqweren,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}acquerre,{/it} going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*acquaerere,{/it} restructuring (by restoring the vocalism of {it}quaerere{/it}) of {it}acquīrere{/it} {ma}{mat|quest:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to come into possession or control of often by unspecified means
to come to have as a new or added characteristic, trait, or ability (as by sustained effort or natural selection)

dt: {bc}to be regarded by people generally (in some particular light)

dt.t: He has {it}acquired a reputation{/it} as a careful worker.

shortdef: to be regarded by people generally (in some particular light)
